API Products

Outline (API Products)

  1. API Products [4]
  2. User Stories [5]
  3. APIs are Languages [7]
  4. Conclusions [2]
API Products Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(3) API First: Everything is an API

  • Jeff Bezos' Mandate [https://gist.github.com/chitchcock/1281611] focuses on API products
    • Loose coupling means to look at products as APIs
    • All dependencies have to be designed and built as APIs
  • API products are built by thinking about interactions
    1. The API is the first UI
    2. APIs are designed before anything is implemented
    3. APIs are the primary means of team communications


API Products Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(4) Strategy → Program → Platform

  • Product platforms are useful to more effectively build complex products
    • Platforms provide foundations for building new products
    • Products contribute to the platform as new components
  • API products are a bit different from regular products
    • API products change often to adapt to changing needs
    • API products can be hard to find in complex landscapes
    • API products have runtime dependencies
  • API platforms are a bit different from regular platforms
    • API platforms are never finished and continuously evolving
    • API platforms ask every product to contribute


API Products Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(5) What is an API Platform?

  • API platforms help with building API products
    • APIs that can be used as part of new APIs
    • Support and tooling for creating APIs as part of an API landscape (API management)
    • Support and tooling for developing APIs (API implementation)
  • API platforms emerge as a result of strategy and programs
    • API Strategy defines what an API platform should encompass
    • API Program defines how to make the platform a reality


API Products Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(6) API Strategy = Pillars × Perspectives

External Internal
Biz
  • API monetization
  • Revenue-supporting APIs
  • Increase speed & feedback
  • Identify & stabilize enablers
  • Design for externalization
  • Increase biz insight with dashboards
Team
  • Focus on documentation/DX
  • Support discovery/self-service
  • Collect DX feedback
  • Products > projects (ownership)
  • Team enablement/support
  • Loose coupling for speed/agility
Tech
  • Tech trends and popularity
  • Invest in onboarding support
  • Secure through platform
  • Loosely coupled implementations
  • Observe patterns and practices
  • Establish C4E for platform/support


User Stories

Outline (User Stories)

  1. API Products [4]
  2. User Stories [5]
  3. APIs are Languages [7]
  4. Conclusions [2]
User Stories Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(8) Focusing on the User (UX)

  • 4-12 steps of user interactions with a product
    • Based on personas that capture goals, motivations, and pains
    • Often based on assumptions of interactions with tangible products
  • For API focus remove any assumptions on specific UI
    • If UI products are the target details can be filled in later
    • If API products are the target there is no need for UI/UX details


User Stories Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(9) Focusing on the Developer (DX)

  • Removing all assumptions about the UI
    • Interactions are simply about information exchanges
    • Interactions can follow various patterns of information exchange
  • Capturing interaction details with some structure can help
    • Capture user story in structured form such as the microservice design canvas [https://www.apiacademy.co/articles/2017/06/the-microservice-design-canvas]
    • Break down complex stories into smaller steps and services
    • Use atomic services as starting points for API design


User Stories Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

APIs are Languages

Outline (APIs are Languages)

  1. API Products [4]
  2. User Stories [5]
  3. APIs are Languages [7]
  4. Conclusions [2]
APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(14) Distributed Problem Solving

  • APIs are part of distributed problem solving
  • Ideal APIs can be used for a range of problems
  • Problem-solving often requires combining APIs
  • Language families make it easier to learn and use new APIs


APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(15) APIs Interactions are Conversations

  • APIs support conversations between interacting peers
    • Some conversations are point-to-point (how to find the peer?)
    • Some conversations are point-to-multipoint (how are groups managed?)
    • Some conversations are point-to-ether (what does the ether do?)
  • API technology does not determine the API conversation style
    • HTTP can be used for asynchronous conversations (WebHooks [http://www.webhooks.org/] pattern)
    • Synchronous conversations can be layered on top of asynchronous foundations
  • Conversation goals should determine the conversation style


APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(16) API Style Metaphors

  • Tunnel: Function calls in procedural programming
  • URI: Data access objects
  • Hypermedia: Browsing the Web
  • Query: Databases and database queries
  • Event: Event-based programming


APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(17) API Styles are Tools



APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(18) API Style Properties

  • API styles influence important API properties
    • Scalability: Number of APIs, API teams, API consumers, and API interactions
    • Usability: Problem domain, established styles, available tooling
    • Changeability: BFF, known/unknown group of consumers
    • Performance: What are critical issues in known scenarios
    • Reliability: Operational concerns and centralization/decentralization


APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(19) Context Considerations

  • Backend for Frontend (BFF) implies tight coupling producer/consumer
    • API style and API design can be coordinated with the consumer
  • Private APIs implies a smaller group of potential consumers
    • Style and design can be guided by internal guidelines/practices
  • Partner APIs implies a well-known group of consumers
    • Broader appeal to consumers necessary
  • Public APIs is the most loosely coupled group of consumers
    • No control over consumers and their preferences/tools and development cycles


APIs are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(20) API Styles in the Wild

  • Tunnel: XML-RPC, SOAP, gRPC, Avro
  • URI: OpenAPI/Swagger, RAML, API Blueprint
  • Hypermedia: HAL, Siren, Atom, HATEOAS
  • Query: GraphQL, OData, SPARQL
  • Event: MQ, WebSub, MQTT, XMPP, AMQP, Kafka


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

  1. API Products [4]

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API

(22) API Product Design

  • API products need well-designed interfaces
  • User stories are way to understand interactions
  • Product interactions are API interactions
  • Products and platforms are tightly intertwined


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Product Journey: From User Story to API
